Title: Narrowing the treatment gap with equitable access: mid-term outcomes of a community case management program in Cameroon
Authors (Date): Littrell M, Moukam LV, Libite R, Youmba JC, Baugh G
Intervention Description:
Community case management for childhood ilnesses. CCM package provided
community-based diagnosis, treatment and referral for suspected
malaria with artemisinin combination therapy (ACT)
and diarrhoeal disease with ORS and zinc through community health workers (PSI)
Outcomes-BH:
Awareness, access and attitudes towards CHW
services among caregivers improved with intervention
B:
Children living in intervention vs comparison
areas were significantly more likely to receive treatment
at a public health facility or through a CHW for fever  and diarrhoea

Appropriate treatment was significantly higher among children
in intervention vs comparison areas including: antimalarial
treatment for fever , ACT
for fever , ORS for
diarrhoea and zinc for
diarrhoea

Title: Addressing Inequities in Access to Health Products through the Use of Social Marketing, Community Mobilization, and Local Entrepreneurs in Rural Western Kenya
Authors (Date): Harris JR, Patel MK, Juliao P, Suchdev PS, Ruth LJ, Were V, Ochieng C, Faith SH, Kola S, Otieno R, Sadumah I, Obure A, Quick R
Journal, Volume (Issue): Page: International Journal of Population Research, 2012, ID 470598
Intervention Description: Social marketing of Water Guard water reatment products, Sprinkles, and insecticide-treated bednets through Safe Water and AIDS project vendors
Outcomes-BH:
At FU1, greater proportions of respondents from intervention households than comparison households who received SWAP vendor visits reported purchasing WaterGuard (14% versus 2%, P < 0.0001), ITNs (3% versus 1%, P < 0.04), and
Sprinkles (36% versus 6%, P < 0.0001) from SWAP vendors.
SMBC: 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

Title: Evaluation of a social marketing intervention promoting oral rehydration salts in Burundi
Authors (Date): Kassegne S, Kays MB, Nzohabonayo J
Population: Females of reproductive age/ 30 households from each of the 115 "collines" in Burundi
Intervention Description: PSI led this social marketing intervention to promote the use of ORASEL for children under five. Campaign included mass media promotion and community outreach (PSI)
Outcomes-BH: Positive changes in behavioral determinants associated with ORASEL use
B:
ORASEL use among caregivers at their children’s last diarrheal episode increased significantly from 20% in
2006 to 30% in 2007.
SMBC: 5:Behavior Customer orientation, Insight, Theory, Mixed methods,

Title: National Scale-up of Zinc Promotion in Nepal: Results from a Post-project Population-based Survey
Authors (Date): Wang W, MacDonald VM, Paudel M, Banke KK
Journal, Volume (Issue): Page: Journal of Health, Population, and Nutrition, 2011, 29 (3): 207-217
Population: Households/Households surveys with children under 6 years of age
Intervention Description:
The Social Marketing Plus for Diarrhoeal Disease Control: Point of Use Water
Disinfection and Zinc Treatment (POUZN) project; Survey regarding knowledge and beliefs about zinc treatment after tha airing of a national mass-media campaign
Outcomes-BH:
Over half (53.1%) of all
caregivers (n=3,550) interviewed had heard about zinc products; most (97.1%) of those who had heard of zinc knew that zinc should be used for the treatment of diarrhoea.
B: At follow-up,  the majority (67.5%) of children (n=289), aged less than six years, with diarrhoea were treated with ORS, and 15.4% were treated with zinc. Children whose caregivers recalled the mass-media message that zinc should be used for 10 days and whose caregivers perceived that zinc is easy to obtain were more likely to be treated with zinc for 10 days, along with ORS
SMBC: 5: Behavior, Theory, Customer orientation, Insight Mixed methods

Title: Increasing equity of access to point-of-use water treatment products through social marketing and entrepreneurship: a case study in western Kenya
Authors (Date): Freeman MC, Quick RE, Abbott DP, Ogutu P, Rheingans R
Population: 487 randomly selected households in eight communities served by the women’s groups
Intervention Description:
Safe Water System is a simple, inexpensive, point-of-use (POU) household water quality intervention using: 1) locally produced sodium hypochlorite
solution for water treatment; 2) safe storage with containers
with a narrow mouth, tight fitting lid and tap; and 3) behaviour change communications; women’s groups in western Kenya were trained to
educate neighbours and sell health products to generate income (PSI)
Outcomes-BH: Knowledge of water treatment products was high
B: 20% (range 5–39%) of households in eight communities purchased and used chlorine, as confirmed by residual chlorine observed in stored water

Title: Bringing Safe Water to Remote Populations: An Evaluation of a Portable Point-of-Use Intervention in Rural Madagascar
Authors (Date): Ram PK, Kelsey E, R, Miarintsoa RR, Rakotomalala O, Dunston C, Quick RE
Population: Respondents from 242 households in 4 villages were interviewed
Intervention Description: Social marketing campaign to promote SWS and SurEau water disinfectant. Campaign used community based sales agents.
Outcomes-BH: Respondents from 239 households (99%) had heard of Sûr’Eau, the SWS disinfectant
B:
226 (95%) reported having ever used Sûr’Eau, and 166 (73%) reported current use. Current Sûr’Eau use was confirmed
in 54% of households.

Title: Acceptability of and Adherence to Dispersible Zinc Tablet in the Treatment of Acute Childhood Diarrhoea
Authors (Date): Nasrin D, Larson, CP, Sultana S, Khan, TU
Journal, Volume (Issue): Page: Journal of Health, Population, and Nutrition, 2005, 23 (3): 215-221
Population: Children between the ages of 3 and 59 months and their caretakers
Intervention Description: Distribution and sales of zinc tablets by a social marketing firm
Outcomes-BH: The formulation was acceptable to children; 90.1% of 303 caretakers perceived that the tablets were equally or even more acceptable to their children compared to other medicines.
B: Ninety-eight percent of the children received the standard dose of one tablet per day, 55.8% completed the full 10-day course of zinc treatment

Title: Social marketing and motivational interviewing as community interventions for safe water behaviors: Follow-up surveys in Zambia
Authors (Date): Thevos AK, Olsen SJ, Kaona FAD, Tembo M, Quick RE
Journal, Volume (Issue): Page: International Quarterly of Community Health Education, 2002, 21 (1): 51-65
Intervention Description: Volunteer community health promoters in experimental (social marketing + motivational interviewing) and comparison (social marketing only) groups trained in causes of diarrhea and prevention through use of Clorin and safe water storage by SFH/Zambia. Health promoters in experimental group additionally trained in MI techniques.  After training, promoters conducted weekly household visits to promote and sell Clorin.
Outcomes-BH: At 3 mos FU, 68% of households in SM group knew of correct disinfectant use vs. 80% in SM+MI group (p>0.05). At 16 mos FU, 80% of households in SM group knoew of correct disinfectant use vs. 89% in SM+MI group (p>0.05).
B: At 3 mos FU in Ndola,48% of households in SM group storing water safely vs. 87% in SM+MI group (p<0.01).  At 16 mos FU in Kitwe, 63% of household in SM group stored water safely vs. 64% in SM+MI group (p>0.05).

Title: Evidence of behaviour change following a hygiene promotion programme in Burkina Faso
Authors (Date): Curtis V, Kanki B, Cousens S, Diallo I, Kpozehouen, Sangare M, Nikiema M
Journal, Volume (Issue): Page: Bulletin of the World Health Organization, 2001, 79 (6): 518-27
Population:
Mothers of
children aged 0–35 months, older sisters, maids, and school-aged children
Intervention Description: Social marketing campaign involving house-to-house visits, performance of plays, and school curriculum
B:
Safe
disposal of children’s stools changed little between 1995 and 1998 (80% pre-intervention, 84% postintervention);
hand-washing with soap after cleaning a child’s bottom rose from 13% to 31% and the proportion of
mothers who washed their hands with soap after using the latrine increased from 1% to 17%.
SMBC: 5: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Segmentation, Methods mix

Title: Analysis of different communication channels for promoting hygiene behavior
Location: Six sub-districts in Khon Kaen province, Thailand
Population: Households from selected villages and random selection of schools - study used questionnaires and FGD
Intervention Description: Social marketing campaign to improve hand and dish-washing practices. Campaign involved both a variety of media outlets as well as village-level health workers
Outcomes-BH: Strong correlation between number of communication channels remembered by respondents and knowledge.
B: No significant improvements in behaviors outside of school children
SMBC: 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Competition, Segmentation,  Mixed Methods
